text: Patient: I thought, I’ve been thinking about chemo. Doctor: Yeah, I appreciate you thinking about it because I think it warrants Patient: Right. Doctor: thinking about you know. So, there’s standard chemo which is the Taxotere that we chatted about which is that once every three weeks for over an hour. Um the studies that we had talked about there’s probably only one that you’re eligible for which is the chemo plus/minus the high-dose vitamin C but that is a pretty intensive treatment where you’re here twice a week Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: for the whole duration. Yeah, so that’s, in talking to you about that last time Patient: Right. Doctor: that’s just too time consuming especially based on where you guys live and so on. Um but, in reviewing your scans it looks like it’s just all in your bones and not thank goodness in the organs or anywhere else. So, there is a liquid radiation that’s available for patients who have, Healthcare Professional: No its okay, I decided to come on in here. Doctor: We were just talking about radium um which is that liquid radiation that only patients who have stuff in their bones not liver or anywhere else would kind of be the right patient to get that medication and that’s like a one-minute injection that the radiation oncology doctors did once a month Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they do that six months so once a month for six months and that’s been shown to help people live longer and that’s actually FDA approved. So, one could run that through the insurance, you know get treated, and be on your way. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: and the chemo. Doctor: the chemo and that’s a nationwide study so, you know, we would pretty much kind of consider that one for you. And then there’s another trial of just pills. You say, listen, Dr. H____ there’s no way your’e giving me any more chemo, get away from me, then there’s a study with two pills so the one pill that I would offer you and then another pill that is also FDA approved but you know in cancer it’s like hey, one’s good, let’s try two. So, the combo isn’t chemo plus pill, but it’s pill plus pill. How are we doing? Patient: I’m there. Doctor: Yeah, I can see it. It’s kind of a lot but the good news is there’s a lot of options and that’s me banking on everything as the worse-case scenario as, you know, you know, Patient: mm hmm. Doctor: that’s how I am because I don’t want you to fret that there’s nothing to do after we get the scans. We have tons of stuff to do. It’s just being thoughtful about what you want in terms of what’s the best thing. Questions? Patient: Not on that. I had one other. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I was just, is it part of the prostate that your bladder don’t empty all the way sometimes? Doctor: Sometimes. Is that acting up? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m worried about and we’ll certainly capture that when we do the scan. Um, are you just peeing like every hour or what’s going on? Patient: It varies. Like the night before I didn’t wake up until like four and then some nights it might be every two hours or couple of hours.

text: Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But most of the things we'll be measuring will be that area by your bladder that was squishing the kidney. So that's a big spot that we really want to keep an eye on. Then of course, bone stuff, but that's an area and you’d want to know that this stuff is shrinking. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Chemo is chemo. So, you know, like we talked about last time, whether it's the pill version or the IV, we always worry about hair loss, you know, tiredness, how it affects your liver numbers, that's measured by blood. We always worry about your white cells, red cells, platelets- Patient: Right, right. Doctor: -you know, all the words that make you you. But that's why you're here getting, you know= Family Member 1: Monitored.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
